html:
4.8.18  8:39 pm   For you, how much of a song is planned out before going into recording in terms of instrumentation?

here

      I know you've said that you like to know the full, exact structure of how the song will go (how long each part is, how many verses/choruses, etc). But do you typically just kind of have a melody in mind,

     and during the recording process is when you come up with the bassline and drum parts and fills and actual arrangement,

      chord voicings,

     and all that stuff? Or do you have each part pretty much in your head before going into it?


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201706030254

6.3.17  2:54 am   Did you follow your chart for your latest song exactly as written or did you change up some chords/notes/lyrics here and there with new bits?

     the version i found from late 2013 was all set. i adhered to that version. that includes melody, chords, lyrics, exact tempo suggestion (112).

     details which were included in that version:
          the exact road map (except shortened the breaks after the choruses, and i let the end go on longer without fading).
          the exact chords in the pre-choruses.
          the answer riff over those chords in both pre-choruses (the organ riff, the one that's the same in both pre-choruses).
          the stray "in"s near the end.
          the modulation in the second chorus.

     details which were added during the recording (2017)
          the pre-intro noises
          all other auxiliary fills and instrumental riffs in response to lines (besides the main one in the late 2nd/3rd verses)
          vocal "yes i went there"
          small vocal prefixes before some of the states ("up in" "even in" etc)
          vocal "what the hell was i gonna say" near the end
          a slight melody variation in the second chorus, on "fool, ohh" which was originally the same as "rules, ohh" from the first chorus
          vocal harmonies

5.18.17  9:29 pm   A favicon would really help us though. When youre like me and you have a lot of tabs, the favicon is the first thing we look at to quickly identify the tab. Sorry about this not being a question I hope you dont mind. To compensate, right after submitting this comment, Ill ask a question.

     ah, that's actually a really good reason. here's my reasoning: i never had an icon or a logo when i made the website. the website was made before the youtube or any of those other channels. i originally wasn't going to use other sites. but i sort of got pressured into it. and all those sites are designed for you to have a profile image, so i had to come up with something. so i never really wanted to use the umbrella, i didn't want to use anything. i just came up with it because i had to use something, and that seemed the most reasonable out of all the options i had. so to use the umbrella on this site seems kind of like taking a step backwards somehow. i would possibly consider doing a favicon but i don't know yet what it would be

4.1.18  10:02 pm   Do you think Michael Jackson would still be highly revered if he didn't die?

     before he died, he had multiple guiness world records including Most Successful Entertainer of All Time, 24 Grammy Awards, 13 AMA awards (more than any other artist of all time), his Thriller album was the highest selling album of all time. He had won hundreds of awards (before dying), more than any other artist in the history of popular music. He shattered all kinds of records and was generally the most popular and successful entertainer/artist in the history of popular music. he reached legendary status well before the end of the 1980s and remained one of the most famous people on the entire planet, for the entire rest of his life. he touched some boys too but that's another story

     Like, do you have to die to be a lengend?

     no

html:
3.26.18  12:28 pm   3.20.18  3:52 pm I don't know if this is exactly what you were talking trying to say, but one thing I took away from it is playing "C Db Eb E F G Ab Bb" over resolving V7 chords. I have done some experimenting with it and I fucking love that sound now! do you have any suggestions for recordings/musicians/eras I could transcribe which use similar sounds/notes to that? 


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201803201552

3.20.18  3:52 pm   3.20.18  3:57 am "C Db, D#, E, Gb, G#, Bb". the same notes as Db melodic minor but starting on C.

     if it were me i'd just say whole tone with the D flipped out to Db and D# instead, IF those notes you listed were the exact notes i needed. probably a lot of people would say altered but i just think there is ambiguity surrounding those situations, both in the terminology and in the reality. in places where the 'altered' scale is typically used, in your key, it would be like if you're on a C7("alt")(which could mean anything from b9 to #9 to +5) about to go to Fmin. and i think in reality your strongest notes are going to be Db, Eb, Bb, Ab, E, and then i'd say tied for the next lesser level of priority would be like F and G, and furthermore this entire umrella of chord scenarios (the C7"alt" to Fmin) in general is very friendly to dense chromatic passing tones, so the remaining notes will immediately go onto the table. this has included some of the notes not in your scale, and also i might add that i think Gb is least likely to be a good choice, actually quite frankly i don't think Gb would belong in the 'altered' scale, if we're talking about what really is strongest for most of the situations where 'alt' is written in the chord symbol. as you study a lot of tunes from the same time period, same composer, etc., you may notice them consistantly using a certain type of 'dark' V7 chord (C7 going to Fmin, in our key) and 'alt' may seem like a friendly concept within the context of one particular time period or composer, but as you travel from decade to decade you'll notice that the 'typical' scenarios become slightly different, and yet still pronounced. some calling strongly for the C7b9, or others more strongly calling for #9 and +5. just when you think you have found the archetypical type within a certain time period or sector of music, move just a few steps and you will find it's different and yet also seemingly archetypical. but i would like to repeat something i said earlier which is sure you can absolutely call your series of notes by either of the 2 previous names first mentioned in the original question, they are perfectly justified names. but be ready to clarify what notes you want if the person says 'what'

C7("alt")(which could mean anything from b9 to #9 to +5) about to go to Fmin. and i think in reality your strongest notes are going to be Db, Eb, Bb, Ab, E, and then i'd say tied for the next lesser level of priority would be like F and G, and furthermore this entire umrella of chord scenarios (the C7"alt" to Fmin) in general is very friendly to dense chromatic passing tones, so the remaining don't think Gb would belong in the 'altered' scale, if we're talking about what really is strongest for most of the situations where 'alt' is written in the chord symbol. as you study a lot of tunes html:
3.20.18  11:25 am   (3.19.18  9:09 pm ) hanon is a death sentence for creativity, in my opinion. but a lot of traditional piano teachers insist on using it. so now people assume it's good i guess. i never liked doing it whne i was being taught, because it was annoying to learn and u can't really play it for fun or for other people to listen because it doesn't sound good

     
(this wasn't a question i just wanted to rant


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201803192109

3.19.18  9:09 pm   3.19.18  3:45 pm https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=n6iFgfzSNw0

     that looks to me like a pretty severe creativity-killing procedure. it's almost like the exercise was designed with the power off
